Program at a Glance

The Art Education major prepares students for a successful career in art teaching. Designed to create exemplary artists and educators, the innovative curriculum includes an exciting range of art education, art studio, and art history courses. TCNJ’s art education graduates are represented in school districts and arts organizations across the region. Upon completing the Bachelor of Arts degree, students qualify for the K-12 New Jersey State Art Teacher Certification.

The program provides students with the necessary knowledge, skills, and dispositions to be effective 21st-century teachers. Beginning in their Sophomore year, students take one art education course each semester through the spring of their Junior year. The sequencing of courses allows students to build upon their knowledge and experience in each course. The The program requires twelve studio courses, four art history courses, and six art education courses. Students conduct coursework that engages varying populations, and they participate in diverse field experiences, thereby fulfilling the race and ethnicity civic responsibility requirement for the College.

Experiential Learning

Art education students have numerous opportunities to exercise their skills and talents; pursue their interests; and gain real-world, hands-on experience beyond the classroom. The program faculty utilize the varied resources of museums and collections in New York City, Philadelphia, Boston, and Washington D.C. with field trips and specialized object research. Students may also participate in faculty-led study tours to destinations such as Cuba, India, Greece, London, and France — or complete a longer study-abroad academic program. Dynamic, student-led organizations like the Rebel Art Movement and Kappa Pi also invite involvement and foster community engagement in the arts, both on and off campus.
